question: Will the Great Lakes ice coverage be less than 15.0% on March 30, 2025?
reasoning:
Based on the information gathered from recent reports on Great Lakes ice coverage:

1. As of March 15, 2025, the consolidated ice coverage for the Great Lakes was reported to be 15.63%. This is slightly above the 15% threshold required for a "YES" resolution to the question.

2. A report from March 18, 2025, indicates that the average ice cover across the Great Lakes was approximately 13.5%. This suggests a decreasing trend in ice coverage as the season progresses.

3. The winter of 2024-2025 has been relatively normal compared to recent years, with ice cover peaking in February at just over 50% due to a polar vortex. However, the ice coverage has been decreasing since then.

Given the current trend of decreasing ice coverage and the fact that the average ice cover was already below 15% as of March 18, it is likely that the ice coverage will continue to decrease and remain below 15% by March 30, 2025.

FINAL PROBABILITY: 0.75

search_results.content:
---
title: Daily Great Lakes Ice Cover Report – March 15, 2025
author: Michael Hardy
url: https://thumbwind.com/2025/03/15/daily-great-lakes-ice-cover-report-march-15-2025/
hostname: thumbwind.com
description: Winter is now waning across the upper Great Lakes region. As ice cover is reduced, changes in weather patterns and lake activities will be seen. This daily Great Lakes ice cover report provides the latest updates on ice conditions across the …
sitename: Thumbwind Publications LLC
date: 2025-03-15
categories: ['News']
tags: ['Great Lakes', 'Ice Cover', 'Lake Erie', 'Lake Michigan', 'Lake Superior', 'Weather Report']
---
Winter is now waning across the upper Great Lakes region. As ice cover is reduced, changes in weather patterns and lake activities will be seen. This daily Great Lakes ice cover report provides the latest updates on ice conditions across the lakes.

**Lake Superior:** 11.54%

**Lake Michigan:** 11.83%

**Lake Huron:** 21.79%

**Lake Erie:** 28.00%

**Lake Ontario:** 11.94%

**Lake St. Clair:** 14.50%

**Great Lakes Consolidated Ice Coverage:** 15.63%

Data from GLERL.NOAA.GOV. Stay tuned for daily updates on Great Lakes ice cover as we monitor changing conditions throughout the season.

search_results.title: https://www.mlive.com/weather/2025/03/see-great-lakes-ice-fade-from-space-and-where-ice-levels-peaked-this-winter.html
search_results.content:
---
title: See Great Lakes ice fade from space, and where ice levels peaked this winter
author: Mark Torregrossa; Mtorregr Com
url: https://www.mlive.com/weather/2025/03/see-great-lakes-ice-fade-from-space-and-where-ice-levels-peaked-this-winter.html
hostname: mlive.com
description: With the warm weather these past few days the ice on the Great Lakes is quickly receding. Here's a look at how the ice cover measured up this winter.
sitename: Mlive
date: 2025-03-11
categories: ['News']
tags: ['@mlive-weather,@mlive-river,@all-mliveriver,michigan-weather']
---
With the warm weather these past few days the ice on the Great Lakes is quickly receding. Here’s a look at how the ice cover measured up this winter.

All of the Great Lakes with the exception of Lake Superior had a peak ice day that eclipsed the long-term peak ice amount.

The ice cover percentage peaked on February 20 for Lake Erie and Lake Ontario. The ice peaked on February 21 for Lakes Superior, Michigan and Huron.

Lake Superior peaked at 46 percent covered with ice on February 21. The long-term average peak ice on Superior is 50 percent.

Lake Michigan peaked at 33 percent covered with ice on February 21. The long-term average peak ice on Lake Michigan is 24 percent.

Lake Huron’s ice cover expanded to 71 percent on February 21. This is 20 percent higher than the long-term average peak ice at 51 percent.

Lake Erie typically has a lot of ice due to the shallow nature of the lake. This year Lake Erie came within 4.2 percent of being deemed totally frozen over.

Lake Ontario usually has the least ice of any Great Lake. This year Ontario peaked at 26 percent covered with ice, compared to a long-term peak of 18 percent.

With the [very warm weather coming late this week](https://www.mlive.com/weather/2025/03/michigans-weather-this-week-suddenly-where-did-winter-go-70-degrees-possible.html) and a warmer-than-normal extended forecast we won’t have ice much longer on the Great Lakes.

## Stories by [Mark Torregrossa](https://www.mlive.com/staff/torregrossa/posts.html)

search_results.content:
---
title: The Great Lakes hit a record low for ice cover last winter. How will this season compare?
author: The Sault News
url: https://www.sooeveningnews.com/story/news/regional/2025/03/18/great-lakes-ice-coverage-hows-it-turning-out-in-2024-25/82514543007/
hostname: sooeveningnews.com
description: As of March 16, average ice cover across the lakes was roughly 13.5%. Lake Superior was at 9.2%, and Lake Michigan was at 10.7%.
sitename: The Sault News
date: 2025-03-18
---
# The Great Lakes hit a record low for ice cover last winter. How will this season compare?

- The 2024-2025 Great Lakes ice season has seen near-normal ice cover, a change from recent years with record lows.
- Ice cover peaked in February at just over 50% due to a polar vortex.
- Climate change continues to cause a long-term decline in Great Lakes ice, impacting the ecosystem and surrounding communities.

This Great Lakes ice season has proven to be much better than the past few years — in fact, it's been relatively normal.

So far, the 2024-'25 ice season has measured up to the [slightly below to near normal conditions predicted](https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/local/2024/12/23/this-years-cold-december-impacts-2024-25-great-lakes-ice-forecast/76961912007/) by the U.S. National Ice Center in December, a reprieve from the record-breaking previous year. During the 2023-2024 ice season, average ice cover across all five lakes was only 4.3% — the lowest on record since scientists began recording ice cover more than 50 years ago, according to data from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The 2022-2023 season was [the fourth lowest](https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/2023/05/26/great-lakes-average-ice-cover-fourth-lowest-in-more-than-50-years/70075822007/) on record at about 6.2%.

So far this winter season, maximum ice cover peaked [at about 52%](https://apps.glerl.noaa.gov/coastwatch/webdata/statistic/ice/dat/g2024_2025_ice.dat) across the Great Lakes after February's polar vortex brought gripping cold to the region. That number is about the same as the long-term average peak.

As of March 16, average ice cover across the lakes was [roughly 13.5%](https://apps.glerl.noaa.gov/coastwatch/webdata/statistic/ice/dat/g2024_2025_ice.dat). And the season is far from over, as ice-off, which marks the end to the ice season, typically happens in April or early May.

Here's what to know about the ice season so far.

## Ice cover across the Great Lakes peaked in mid-February

The U.…

content.snippet:
---
title: See Great Lakes ice fade from space, and where ice levels peaked this winter
author: Mark Torregrossa; Mtorregr Com
url: https://www.mlive.com/weather/2025/03/see-great-lakes-ice-fade-from-space-and-where-ice-levels-peaked-this-winter.html
hostname: mlive.com
description: With the warm weather these past few days the ice on the Great Lakes is quickly receding. Here's a look at how the ice cover measured up this winter.
sitename: Mlive
date: 2025-03-11
categories: ['News']
tags: ['@mlive-weather,@mlive-river,@all-mliveriver,michigan-weather']
---
With the warm weather these past few days the ice on the Great Lakes is quickly receding. Here’s a look at how the ice cover measured up this winter.

All of the Great Lakes with the exception of Lake Superior had a peak ice day that eclipsed the long-term peak ice amount.

The ice cover percentage peaked on February 20 for Lake Erie and Lake Ontario. The ice peaked on February 21 for Lakes Superior, Michigan and Huron.

Lake Superior peaked at 46 percent covered with ice on February 21. The long-term average peak ice on Superior is 50 percent.

Lake Michigan peaked at 33 percent covered with ice on February 21. The long-term average peak ice on Lake Michigan is 24 percent.

Lake Huron’s ice cover expanded to 71 percent on February 21. This is 20 percent higher than the long-term average peak ice at 51 percent.

Lake Erie typically has a lot of ice due to the shallow nature of the lake. This year Lake Erie came within 4.2 percent of being deemed totally frozen over.

Lake Ontario usually has the least ice of any Great Lake. This year Ontario peaked at 26 percent covered with ice, compared to a long-term peak of 18 percent.

With the [very warm weather coming late this week](https://www.mlive.com/weather/2025/03/michigans-weather-this-week-suddenly-where-did-winter-go-70-degrees-possible.html) and a warmer-than-normal extended forecast we won’t have ice much longer on the Great Lakes.

## Stories by [Mark Torregrossa](https://www.mlive.com/staff/torregrossa/posts.html)

With the warm weather these past few days the ice on the Great Lakes is quickly receding. Here’s a look at how the ice cover measured up this winter.

All of the Great Lakes with the exception of Lake Superior had a peak ice day that eclipsed the long-term peak ice amount.

The ice cover percentage peaked on February 20 for Lake Erie and Lake Ontario. The ice peaked on February 21 for Lakes Superior, Michigan and Huron.

Lake Superior peaked at 46 percent covered with ice on February 21. The long-term average peak ice on Superior is 50 percent.

Lake Michigan peaked at 33 percent covered with ice on February 21. The long-term average peak ice on Lake Michigan is 24 percent.

Lake Huron’s ice cover expanded to 71 percent on February 21. This is 20 percent higher than the long-term average peak ice at 51 percent.

Lake Erie typically has a lot of ice due to the shallow nature of the lake. This year Lake Erie came within 4.2 percent of being deemed totally frozen over.

Lake Ontario usually has the least ice of any Great Lake. This year Ontario peaked at 26 percent covered with ice, compared to a long-term peak of 18 percent.

With the [very warm weather coming late this week](https://www.mlive.com/weather/2025/03/michigans-weather-this-week-suddenly-where-did-winter-go-70-degrees-possible.html) and a warmer-than-normal extended forecast we won’t have ice much longer on the Great Lakes.

## Stories by [Mark Torregrossa](https://www.mlive.com/staff/torregrossa/posts.html)", "word_count": 300, "snippet_word_count": 300, "snippet_truncated": false, "date_cutoff_start": "2025-02-23T08:38:42.125823", "date_cutoff_end": "2025-03-24T08:38:42.125823", "cached_at": "2025-10-24T06:37:45.655935"}

content.snippet:
---
title: The Great Lakes hit a record low for ice cover last winter. How will this season compare?
author: The Sault News
url: https://www.sooeveningnews.com/story/news/regional/2025/03/18/great-lakes-ice-coverage-hows-it-turning-out-in-2024-25/82514543007/
hostname: sooeveningnews.com
description: As of March 16, average ice cover across the lakes was roughly 13.5%. Lake Superior was at 9.2%, and Lake Michigan was at 10.7%.
sitename: The Sault News
date: 2025-03-18
---
# The Great Lakes hit a record low for ice cover last winter. How will this season compare?

- The 2024-2025 Great Lakes ice season has seen near-normal ice cover, a change from recent years with record lows.
- Ice cover peaked in February at just over 50% due to a polar vortex.
- Climate change continues to cause a long-term decline in Great Lakes ice, impacting the ecosystem and surrounding communities.

This Great Lakes ice season has proven to be much better than the past few years — in fact, it's been relatively normal.

So far, the 2024-'25 ice season has measured up to the [slightly below to near normal conditions predicted](https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/local/2024/12/23/this-years-cold-december-impacts-2024-25-great-lakes-ice-forecast/76961912007/) by the U.S. National Ice Center in December, a reprieve from the record-breaking previous year. During the 2023-2024 ice season, average ice cover across all five lakes was only 4.3% — the lowest on record since scientists began recording ice cover more than 50 years ago, according to data from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The 2022-2023 season was [the fourth lowest](https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/2023/05/26/great-lakes-average-ice-cover-fourth-lowest-in-more-than-50-years/70075822007/) on record at about 6.2%.

So far this winter season, maximum ice cover peaked [at about 52%](https://apps.glerl.noaa.gov/coastwatch/webdata/statistic/ice/dat/g2024_2025_ice.dat) across the Great Lakes after February's polar vortex brought gripping cold to the region. That number is about the same as the long-term average peak.

As of March 16, average ice cover across the lakes was [roughly 13.5%](https://apps.glerl.noaa.gov/coastwatch/webdata/statistic/ice/dat/g2024_2025_ice.dat). And the season is far from over, as ice-off, which marks the end to the ice season, typically happens in April or early May.

Here's what to know about the ice season so far.

## Ice cover across the Great Lakes peaked in mid-February

The U.…

[Truncated preview: showing 336 words out of ~1033. Full content available via `btf_extract_evidence`.]

messages.content:
Based on the following question, analyze it carefully and provide your probability estimate.

Question: Will the Great Lakes ice coverage be less than 15.0% on March 30, 2025?
Background: Please see the resources by the Great Lakes Environmental Research Laboratory [here](https://www.glerl.noaa.gov/data/ice/#currentConditions).
Resolution criteria: This question resolves as YES if the 'GL Total' figure for Great Lakes average ice concentration according to [this data set](https://apps.glerl.noaa.gov/coastwatch/webdata/statistic/ice/dat/g2024_2025_ice.dat) for the 89th day of 2025 is less than 15.0%. Otherwise, it resolves as NO.
Fine print: If the resolution source fails to update before the end of this tournament, then the most recent day preceding day 89 will be used to resolve the question.
present_date: 2025-03-23T08:38:42.125823


Make sure to use the tools at your disposal to gather relevant information before providing your final probability estimate.

You may reason through the problem, but you MUST end your response with:
FINAL PROBABILITY: [your decimal number between 0 and 1]

Otherwise, it resolves as NO.","fine_print":"If the resolution source fails to update before the end of this tournament, then the most recent day preceding day 89 will be used to resolve the question.","present_date":"2025-03-23T08:38:42.125823"}

author: Michael Hardy

hostname: thumbwind.com
description: Winter is now waning across the upper Great Lakes region. As ice cover is reduced, changes in weather patterns and lake activities will be seen. This daily Great Lakes ice cover report provides the latest updates on ice conditions across the …
sitename: Thumbwind Publications LLC
date: 2025-03-15
categories: ['News']
tags: ['Great Lakes', 'Ice Cover', 'Lake Erie', 'Lake Michigan', 'Lake Superior', 'Weather Report']
---
Winter is now waning across the upper Great Lakes region. As ice cover is reduced, changes in weather patterns and lake activities will be seen. This daily Great Lakes ice cover report provides the latest updates on ice conditions across the lakes.

**Lake Superior:** 11.54%

**Lake Michigan:** 11.83%

**Lake Huron:** 21.79%

**Lake Erie:** 28.00%

**Lake Ontario:** 11.94%

**Lake St. Clair:** 14.50%

**Great Lakes Consolidated Ice Coverage:** 15.63%

Data from GLERL.NOAA.GOV. {"url": "https://www.mlive.com/weather/2025/03/see-great-lakes-ice-fade-from-space-and-where-ice-levels-peaked-this-winter.html", "snippet": "---
title: See Great Lakes ice fade from space, and where ice levels peaked this winter
author: Mark Torregrossa; Mtorregr Com
url: https://www.mlive.com/weather/2025/03/see-great-lakes-ice-fade-from-space-and-where-ice-levels-peaked-this-winter.html
hostname: mlive.com
description: With the warm weather these past few days the ice on the Great Lakes is quickly receding. Here's a look at how the ice cover measured up this winter.
sitename: Mlive
date: 2025-03-11
categories: ['News']
tags: ['@mlive-weather,@mlive-river,@all-mliveriver,michigan-weather']
---
With the warm weather these past few days the ice on the Great Lakes is quickly receding. Here’s a look at how the ice cover measured up this winter.

All of the Great Lakes with the exception of Lake Superior had a peak ice day that eclipsed the long-term peak ice amount.

The ice cover percentage peaked on February 20 for Lake Erie and Lake Ontario. The ice peaked on February 21 for Lakes Superior, Michigan and Huron.

Lake Superior peaked at 46 percent covered with ice on February 21. The long-term average peak ice on Superior is 50 percent.

Lake Michigan peaked at 33 percent covered with ice on February 21. The long-term average peak ice on Lake Michigan is 24 percent.

Lake Huron’s ice cover expanded to 71 percent on February 21. This is 20 percent higher than the long-term average peak ice at 51 percent.

Lake Erie typically has a lot of ice due to the shallow nature of the lake. This year Lake Erie came within 4.2 percent of being deemed totally frozen over.

Lake Ontario usually has the least ice of any Great Lake. This year Ontario peaked at 26 percent covered with ice, compared to a long-term peak of 18 percent.

With the [very warm weather coming late this week](https://www.mlive.com/weather/2025/03/michigans-weather-this-week-suddenly-where-did-winter-go-70-degrees-possible.html) and a warmer-than-normal extended forecast we won’t have ice much longer on the Great Lakes.

messages.content:
Based on the information gathered from recent reports on Great Lakes ice coverage:

1. As of March 15, 2025, the consolidated ice coverage for the Great Lakes was reported to be 15.63%. This is slightly above the 15% threshold required for a "YES" resolution to the question.

2. A report from March 18, 2025, indicates that the average ice cover across the Great Lakes was approximately 13.5%. This suggests a decreasing trend in ice coverage as the season progresses.

3. The winter of 2024-2025 has been relatively normal compared to recent years, with ice cover peaking in February at just over 50% due to a polar vortex. However, the ice coverage has been decreasing since then.

Given the current trend of decreasing ice coverage and the fact that the average ice cover was already below 15% as of March 18, it is likely that the ice coverage will continue to decrease and remain below 15% by March 30, 2025.

FINAL PROBABILITY: 0.75
